titleInfo.title: 234HA3 Hixon Mound Site 1HA3, Hamilton Co., Tennessee. View of Feature 55 (Structure) the central, circular firebasin (Feature 78). Direction east

mods.abstract: The postmolds in the left foreground corner were washed away during heavy rains. [Feature 55] Burned clay floor and rectangular postmold pattern at Floor R level. The floor of this structure consisted of burned packed clay. The quantity of charred superstructure (cane, bark, thatch and logs) on the floor suggest that the structure had burned, possibly explaining the thorough burning of the floor. The vertical posts were set in trenches about 1.5' deep - the ends of the posts protruding through the bottom of the trench. Segmented horizontal log molds were laid in the trenches high on the interior and low on the exterior (about 0.5' below the floor inside and about 1.2' below the floor on the outside.) The trenches extended nearly to the corners of the structure, however, at least one, two, or three of the corner posts were not set in trenches. The corner posts are smaller and not over 1.0' deep. Several interior postmolds suggest the presence of furniture. A fill of about 0.5' (average) intervened between the floor and the top of the old humus layer (Level #2). [Feature 78] Circular fire pit with modeled rim in center of Feature 55. This appeared to be a simple fire pit with modeled, burned clay rim and sides. However, excavation shows that the original shape of the interior pit had been altered by an additional plastering of clay about 1.0' to 0.2 thick. The pit was originally jug-shaped, however the additional plastering had left the sides straight giving the hole the appearance of a cylinder. The floor had evidently been burned hard before the pit was dug through it as the edges were jagged and rough, though hidden by the rounded modeled rim. The body of the rim had been built up of grayish made soil.
mods.note: Institution has drawings for Features 55 and 78 on file. See also photographs 231HA3 [fhm00901] and 233HA3 [fhm00902] for other views of these features.
